AddVariableNameHint: Name the variable that you want to extract from {{name}} . i.e. "Number of diagnostics".
CloneProjectInfo: This action will clone this project, and all related input. Confirm to clone.
CrossCuttingInfo: Cross-cutting indicators are determined from the list of thematics in "Basics".
This list contains all cross-cutting indicators that your project need to collect

DataSourceEdit.AddNameHint: What is the name of the data source that you want to extract data from? i.e. "Electronic medical record", "Health center tally sheet", "NHIS report", ...
DataSourceEdit.AddNamePlaceholder: For instance: NHIS data, Ante-natal care tally sheet, PHC tally sheet, ...
DataSourceEdit.CollectionSitesHint: Among sites identified in "Collection sites", which one collect this data source?
DataSourceEdit.EndDateHint: If this data source will end before the end of the project, or was replaced, enter the date here
DataSourceEdit.PeriodicityHint: How often is this data available? Take care, this is not the same thing as the frenquency of the reports that you need to provide.
DataSourceEdit.StartDateHint: If this data source was created after the beginning of the project, enter here the date, otherwise, leave the default value

Disaggregation.AddNameHint: This name will appear on multiple reporting tables. It names the disaggregation that you want to create on your variable
Disaggregation.AddNamePlaceholder: ex: Age group, gender, motive for consultation, pathology, referral status, ...
Disaggregation.AggregationHint: How to find the total value by aggregating the elements described above?
Disaggregation.ElementsHint: Elements from the disaggregation must be mutually exclusive, and it should be possible to find the total value by aggregating them.
Disaggregation.ElementsPlaceholder: ex: Less than 12 years old, male, social consultation, flu, community referral, ...
Disaggregation.DisplayTitle: Where should disaggregation elements be displayed on the forms?
Disaggregation.DisplayHint: If you wish to print the forms in A4 format, prefer having the titles at the left of the tables, to shorten their width.
Disaggregation.OrderTitle: In which order should the disaggregations be shown?
Disaggregation.OrderHint: How do you wish to show the disaggregations on the input form?
Disaggregation.Title: Titles

Aggregation.none: It's not possible to compute this

Periodicity.month_week_sat: Every weeks (saturday to friday / split by month)
Periodicity.month_week_sun: Every weeks (sunday to saturday / split by month)
Periodicity.month_week_mon: Every weeks (monday to sunday / split by month)

Computation.unavailable: It is not possible to compute this indicator
Computation.copy: Copy a value (from a data source)

EquivalentVersion: This version is equivalent to the current state of the project
ExtraIndicatorsInfo: Extra indicators are indicators that are not in any logical framework.
Those allow to monitor specific elements of the project (medical data, logistics, ...)
GeoAggregation: How to group entries from different sites?
GeoAggregationHint: In a project with two sites, if {{name}}  is 10 for the first and 20 for the second, what is the value for the complete project?

OnlinePlatform.Title: Why an online platform
Cards:
Increase reliability

  • Have consistency checks on data to limit entry errors
  • Limit mistakes in calculation

Step back

  • Encourage geographically remote projects to use the same indicators when measuring comparable events
  • Have mechanisms to compare the value of an indicator on a project, with the same value for all other that collected it

Ease communication

  • Provide direct access to project's data to all departments in the NGO (management, communication, ...)
  • Have single source of truth between headquarters and field project

Standardize

  • Ease turn-over by limiting the number of different tools used across projects
  • Reduce the learning curve required to consult data on a new project

When.Title: When should you use Monitool
When.SubTitle: Monitool plays a role during four stages of a project

Cards.Title: Design of the logical frame
Cards.Text: Monitool provides all others projets logframes, with the list of used indicators and targets for each one of them

Cards.Title: Deployment of monitoring tools
Cards.Text: Explicitely write down the path followed by your data and attach deadlines on data collection

Cards.Title: Periodic follow-up
Cards.Text: Reporting graphs and tables of your choice are available and built with the most up-to-date data

Cards.Title: After closing
Cards.Text: Your project will be archived and available for future references

KeepInMind.Title: Keep in mind
Cards:
Monitool is all about monitoring.

It contributes to the ongoing, continuous and systematic monitoring of the situation and its evolution throughout the life of a project.

Its goal is to help taking decisions, thanks to the continuous follow-up of indicators that provide information on the progress of activities, and their contribution to the expected outputs and outcomes decided for your project.

Even if it can contribute to it, it's primary goal is not to do epidemiologic monitoring, or centralize morbidity sheets which are time-consuming and have little value in project management, specially for projects that support health structure (in opposition with providing direct care).

GettingStarted.Title: Getting started
GettingStarted.SubTitle: Before setting your project up in Monitool, some preliminary steps can help you
Cards: Design your reference project: logical framework with output and outcomes indicators, process indicators can be added if necessary

Use the Indicators summary tool to document all indicators from your reference project, and possibly donor's projects (if they are different)

  • Why: How is each indicator going to help measuring the output or outcome that is expected from your activities? How do you plan on analysing it (graphs, tables, with which periodicity: you need to plan in advance how your data will be used for decision making)
  • How: identify all data and disagregations that will be needed to compute each one of your indicators
  • When, where, by and for whom?

Build a dataflow chart from the indicator's summary to draw how data will flow in your project

  • The data sources organized according to the project's structure
  • Detail collected data and precise disagregations
  • Organize your indicators by logical framework

Guides.Title: Guides & Documents supports
Cards:
• Healthcare project planning (2015)

    Healthcare project planning offers MdM project players a method of planning that is in line with the values reaffirmed and specified in that statement – to provide care and cure, to bear witness and advocate, and to support communities seeking social change.

  • Toolbox for healthcare project planning

    This toolbox contains multiple tools, mostly Excel-based in order to help you formalizing your project's planning.

  • DSP's Monitoring library

    This library contains fact sheets, training documents and position papers connected with monitoring and maintained by the DSP department.

OtherTools.Title: Other tools
Cards:
• Indicator's summary

    Available in the essentials documents for monitoring archive , this tool centralize for all of your indicators the "when", "how", "where", "by whom" and "for whom" the data that you handle should be collected and analized.

  • Dataflow chart

    In the same archive, this tool schematize the path that your data follows, from the form that was used to collect it, to the report or decision making that it enabled.

IndicatorEditionPlaceholder.Description: We are not talking about health education, but training of medical staff. Count the number of entries and not the number of different people who attended these trainings.
IndicatorEditionPlaceholder.Name: Training volume

IndicatorMissingDescription: The description of this indicator was not filled
InputsInfo: This input calendar list all the inputs that were programmed for the data source
To limit data entry errors, the preferred course is to do the data entry close from the site where the data is extracted, directly on monitool.
If not attainable, a PDF version of the form is provided.
InputHomeInfo: This section's goal is providing the data that will allow to compute your indicators to Monitool.
Each one of the data sources that were created during the structuration of the project results in a periodic form that need to be filled.
When entering data, the Tab key on your keyboard allows you to navigate between the boxes.
To return to the previous box, use Shift + Tab
A printable version of each forms is available.
If you have several paper forms to enter (for example, one per social worker), and want to add them, you can enter sums in the entry boxes: "1 + 2 + 3"

LogicalFrameworksPageDescription.Line1: A logical framework is a document that describe objectives, expected results, and actities to achieve them, as well as indicators to monitor the advancement of each of those elements
LogicalFrameworksPageDescription.Line2: All indicators have to be computable from the data described in data sources

Name: Name
NoExtraIndicator: No extra indicator has been created yet. Click on "Add indicator" to create one!
Partitions: Which disaggregations should be used on this variable?
PartitionsHint: Do we want to be able to differenciate {{name}} by age, gender, type of care, consultation motive, pathology, hour of the day, referral type, ...? Do not disaggregate by location: your collection sites were already filled in the relevant page.

Add.Thematic: Add a new thematic to the project

ProjectBasicsInfo: Basics allow to file your project among the others of the NGO.
ProjectDataSourceInfo: The data sources are the different supports where the data needed for monitoring are available (tally sheets, medical records, excel files, ...).
In Monitool, all the data avaiable on the data sources does not need to be entered, but only what is relevat to the project's monitorings
To ease the data collection planning, data sources should correspond to real tools used on the field.
ProjectHistoryInfo: The changelog allows to consult all modifications that were made to the structure of your project, and revert to previous revisions if needed.
ProjectHomeBlueSection: Use short names to name collection sites, data sources, variables, and indicators. By avoiding acronyms you improve the readability of your charts and tables and allow a better understanding of your project by all actors of Doctors of the World.
to return to the last saved version.
If you saved a mistake: go to the
page and restore an earlier version of the project.
ProjectHomeInfo: This section will help you formalize your project. It must be used during the project planning phase and then revised during the project implementation phase.
Use your data flow chart to structure your project in Monitool. If you have followed all the steps, you have all the necessary elements.
Document the objectives and expected results of your project
Document the activities you will do to reach them
List the indicators that will measure the achievement of your results, as well as the monitoring of your activities (process indicators)

List your data collection tools (Excel, paper, ...) as well as other sources of data (NHIS, surveys ...) that you will use to calculate your indicators, by informing their periodicity and collection sites and their contents
ProjectSitesInfo: When a project have the same activities on different sites, those activities need to be followed-up by site, groups of sites, and at project level.
The list of sites where your project works (i.e. the list of health centers)
Groups that will be used during monitoring (i.e. by region, or type of structure)
ProjectsUserInfo: Many people take part in setting-up and monitoring a project: coordination, M&E staff, data entry operators, partners, ...
Enter here all users that need to have access to the monitoring of the project.
ReportingHomeBlueSection: in order to display a graph that contains the data of the current row.
in order to disaggregate the data of the current row.
symbol means that one of the steps taken to compute your indicador failed.

The most likely is that you have divided by zero, that all the data was not entered, or that you have explicitly indicated that it was not possible to aggregate this data when setting up your data source.
allow you to restrict the data that you consult on certain dates, collection sites, or according to the disaggregations specified during the creation of your project (age groups, sex, ...).
ReportingHomeInfo: This section allows you to track your project progress.
allows you to access all of your data, in different way.
Allows you to explore your data hierarchically: starting from a general vision of your project.

You can consult each logical framework or data source, which contains indicators, which you can then disaggregate by collection site, parameter that you used to calculate them, and other disaggregations according to the data structure that you collected (age range, sex, pathologies, training content, ...).
SaveConfirm: Save to confirm reverting to this version
SettingsIndicatorEdit: This page allows changing the definition of a cross-cutting indicator. If you make changes, take care to update all languages.
SettingsIndicatorsInfo: This page contain the list of all the cross-cutting indicators of the NGO.
Collecting each indicator is mandatory for all projects that have at least one thematic in common with it.
To allow projects to plan for their data collection, avoid changing this list often.
SettingsThematicsEdit: Enter here the name of the thematic in all languages used by your organisation.
SettingsThematicsInfo: This page contains the list of thematics handled by the NGO.
Projects and cross-cutting indicators can be linked to thematics.
SettingsUserEdit: You can edit the permissions of other users here. Click on "Show help for this field" to have more details on the different kinds of permissions that are available.
SettingsUserInfo: This page contains the list of all users that connected at least once on Monitool

It is not needed to create new account for users that have a xxx@medecinsdumonde.net email address: they will automatically appear here once they connect once. For partners, it is possible to create account from the project management pages.
TimeAggregation: How to group entries from different periods?
TimeAggregationHint: In a project collecting monthly data, if {{name}}  is 10 in january, 20 in february and 30 in march, what is the value for the first quarter?

BasicsEdition.Country: In which country does your project takes place? If it's a regional project enter the name of the region.
BasicsEdition.EndDate: The end date is the moment when your project closes its data collection. If unknown, enter a date far into the future.
BasicsEdition.Name: The project's name allow finding your project in Monitool. Choose something that is informative enought, or copy the general objective.
BasicsEdition.StartDate: The begin date is the moment when your projects starts collecting data (usually, with the first activities).
BasicsEdition.Thematics: The thematics that you choose will determine which cross-cutting indicators your project will need to collect.
BasicsEdition.Visibility: Outside of specific cases, all projects should be visible for all users.

UserEdition.Role: This field determines what will this user be allowed to do: owners can change the project's structure, data entry officers can only do data input.
UserEdition.Type: Choose "MDM Account" if the user has a xxx@medecinsdumonde.net email address. Choose "Partner account" otherwise.
UserEdition.User: Who is the MDM user that you want to add? If the user is not in the list, ask him/her to log-in Monitool a first time.

VisibilityPrivate: Visible only to members of this project
WrongCredentials: Wrong username or password. Please try again
specific-date-start: Please choose the specific start date
specific-date-end: Please choose the specific end date
Colorize-Hint: Do you wish to have colors (red, orange, green) on reporting for this indicator?
Computation-Hint: Please choose the appropriate calculation method
Name-Hint2: Make sure you put the correct name for each language
description-Hint: Make sure you put the correct description for each language
